importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication indicates the most recent update on the incident involving Doug Martin's death, providing context for public awareness and ongoing investigations.

This date marks when the Oakland Police Department, city officials, and the Alameda County Coroner's Office made public statements regarding the circumstances of Martin’s death, emphasizing the timeline of events.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The entire incident, including the arrest and subsequent death, occurred around the same time frame, with the arrest happening on Saturday and the death reported on Monday, highlighting a rapid and tragic sequence of events.

keyTakeAways: Doug Martin, a former All-Pro NFL running back, died after being arrested during a police investigation into a home break-in in Oakland.
Martin was involved in a brief struggle with officers, and became unresponsive shortly after being taken into custody, leading to his hospitalization and eventual death.
A cause of death has not been released, and an autopsy is scheduled, indicating that the official cause remains under investigation.
Martin, originally from Oakland and raised in Stockton, had a distinguished NFL career with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, where he was named first-team All-Pro and selected for the Pro Bowl twice.

Former agent Brian Murphy revealed that Martin struggled with mental health challenges, which significantly affected his personal and professional life and contributed to his actions on the night of the arrest.
Martin’s parents sought medical help and contacted authorities when he became overwhelmed and disoriented, leading him to flee into a neighbor’s home where police found him.
The Oakland Police Department, the city mayor, and multiple agencies including the community police review body and district attorney’s office are involved in the investigation.
The event has sparked broader public conversation about mental health in athletes and the responsibilities of law enforcement during high-stress situations.
Martin is recognized as one of the top 50 players in Tampa Bay Buccaneers history, underscoring his significance in professional football.
The article is part of a larger AP news coverage on NFL-related events and public tragedies, increasing its relevance to sports and societal health discourse.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Doug Martin, a former All-Pro NFL running back with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, died at age 36 after being arrested during a police investigation into a break-in at a home in Oakland, California. A brief struggle with officers led to him becoming unresponsive, and he later died in a hospital. His former agent, Brian Murphy, revealed that Martin had long struggled with mental health issues, which profoundly affected his life and may have contributed to the incident. The Oakland Police Department, mayor Barbara Lee, and the Alameda County Coroner’s Office are involved in the investigation, with no cause of death released as of the reporting date. Martin, originally from Oakland and raised in Stockton, is remembered as a standout athlete and one of the franchise’s top players, with a legacy highlighted by his recognition in the Buccaneers’ 50th-anniversary celebration.
title: Former NFL Star Doug Martin Dies After Arrest in Oakland Break-In Investigation
